docs.lead_paragraph: THERE SEEMED TO BE mirrors everywhere, and there we stood, reflected over and over, great black bumblebees in our leotards, pregnant women exercising. We stretched our necks and shoulders, worked our thighs, pulled in the long-suffering abdominal muscles that had so much to hold. ''Hug your baby,'' said the instructor as we tried in vain to flatten our stomachs. The classes were held in a racquetball club, and I remember the morning when two men in tennis whites stumbled in upon us by mistake. Ashen, they backed out, mumbling excuses; we were the ones who laughed as we continued our leg lifts.

byline.original: BY ANNA QUINDLEN; Anna Quindlen writes the ''Life in the 30's'' column for The Times
